Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Eyes of the Foreseer - Integrative and In Situ Information Retrieval and Mining in Online Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the growth of online communities, the Web has evolved from networks of shared documents to networks of knowledge-sharing groups and individuals. A vast amount of heterogeneous yet interrelated information is being generated for which existing information analysis techniques are inadequate. Current tools often neglect the actual creators and consumers of information, and as a result, the findings are only useful to data analysts.

The user-centric Foreseer is the next generation of information analysis for online communities. It represents a new paradigm of study through the four "C's": content, context, crowd, and cloud. Information analysis of content is put into the context of the users' daily lives to benefit the communities (crowd) that generate information residing in the cloud. This project provides integrative and in situ analysis of information generated in online communities that is of the people, by the people, and for the people. Research of Foreseer consists of formal community models, efficient data analysis tools, advanced solutions of real applications, and novel information systems.

Making the results available to everyday Web users, not just data analysts, will result in improved dissemination of ideas, shared public opinions, and wise decision-making in online communities. Novel Web-based information systems will form prototypes that can be used in online social and health communities. The research will enhance the current information analysis and retrieval curricula and lead to a number of new classes in information science and health informatics. Research results will also be published on the project Web site (http://www-personal.umich.edu/~qmei/foreseer/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid growth of online communities has influenced every aspect of our daily lives. Online communities are often associated with a variety of information that is created, distributed, and consumed by their users. Existing data analysis tools often neglect the actual creators and consumers of information, and as a result, the findings are only useful to data analysts. In this project, we developed novel computational techniques that facilitate users to search, analyze, and discover useful knowledge from the rich information in online communities. These techniques are user-centric, which focus on how to analyze user-generated data, how to involve the users into the loop of data analysis, and how to make use of the analysis results to benefit the users who own the data and who have contributed to the analysis procedure.


We developed a family of computational methods to process and analyze the rich and big data in online communities. These methods successfully collect, retrieve, characterize, mine, visualize, and make predictions from content, networks, contexts, user behaviors, and other types of information. These new techniques have been successfully applied to data sets and real-world tasks in online social communities, health communities, microfinance communities, and academic communities. For example, we developed a pipeline that processes the stream of 50 million Tweets everyday, detects and tracks emerging rumors from the stream, visualizes the influence of these rumor cascades on the audience, and predicts the future impact of these cascades. The key to these successful applications is to involve the real users to provide guidance and feedbacks during the procedure, through a set of techniques known as interactive machine learning.


These methods do not end at analyzing data sets or making predictions. Instead, we developed systems and experiments that directly utilize the data analysis results to change people’s behaviors in online communities for social good. For example, our analysis showed that team competition increases lending activities in an online microfinance community, Kiva.org, where people make interest-free loans to small entrepreneurs in third-world countries. We then developed a system to recommend Kiva users to join teams. We found that Kiva lenders were more likely to join teams with members from similar locations, and those who joined the recommended teams made significantly more loans after joining.  A similar mechanism has been applied to a leading ride-sharing community, where team recommendation and team competition have successfully promoted the productivity of hundreds of thousands of drivers.


Research work in this project has generated more than 40 publications in top notch journals and peer-reviewed conferences, such as the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, the International Conference of Machine Learning, and the Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association. Four papers have won or been nominated for best paper awards in top conferences. The PI himself was awarded a distinguished member of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) for outstanding contributions to computing. Research results of the project have been disseminated to the broad audience through technical talks at academic institutes and companies, tutorials and invited talks at conferences, reports by news media in more than 30 countries, and introductory talk to local high school students. Many of the techniques, data sets, and educational materials have been open sourced and disseminated through the project Website.


Research of the project has also been closely integrated into education. More than 10 doctoral, masters, and undergraduate students have participated in the project, advanced their knowledge and training in data science, and moved on to the next era of their careers in academia or industry. The PI designed and offered multiple graduate and undergraduate courses in the University of Michigan to teach classical and state-of-the-art data science techniques to hundreds of students. In the graduate-level information retrieval and data mining courses, the PI explored a major academic innovation and used data science competitions to replace traditional homework assignments. Many of these competitions, which were highly reviewed by the students, directly used data sets and research tasks from this project.


Through working on this project, we developed an end-to-end view of the broader field of applied data science, that is, a data science of the people, by the people, and for the people. This new perspective becomes a general philosophy behind the newly designed online master degree of applied data science, to be offered by the University of Michigan in Fall 2019.
